Award.AwardTitle: Texas A&M University System LSAMP: Sustaining the Progress

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The Texas A&M LSAMP is an Alliance of three universities in Texas - Texas A&M University (TAMU), Texas A&M University - Corpus Christi (TAMUCC), and Prairie View A&M University (PVAMU). TAMUCC is an HSI and PVAMU is an HBCU. This Alliance is requesting a renewal of LSAMP funding to focus on determining and sharing promising practices to continue increasing STEM enrollment, B.S. graduation rates, and preparation for graduate school for URM students. The goal of the project is to sustain and institutionalize successful prior LSAMP efforts and refine strategies for increasing the number of well-prepared URM students attaining STEM B.S. degrees, who are globally competitive and motivated to pursue a graduate education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Texas A&M University System Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (TAMUS LSAMP) was one of the first six AMPs funded by NSF in 1991, and has been continuously funded since. Through a suite of opportunities designed for underrepresented minority (URM) undergraduate (UG) students, the Alliance has demonstrated its impact across a range of academic success indicators. 

The Alliance has helped catalyze the development, implementation, and institutionalization of prior LSAMP efforts and innovative strategies for increasing the number of well-prepared URM STEM students who are globally competitive and motivated to pursue graduate education at member institutions. Over the years, TAMUS LSAMP strategies have focused on academic and social integration as described in the Tinto Theory of Student Retention, on which the LSAMP model is based.

During the Sustaining the Progress (Renewal) project, the three TAMUS LSAMP partner institutions (Texas A&M University, Prairie View A&M University, and Texas A&M University-Corpus Christi) supported undergraduate research (UGR) throughout the academic year, including summer research and international experiences. Professional development seminars augmented students' research experiences.

UGR participants attended and presented their research at professional organization meetings and conferences. TAMUS LSAMP also held its own symposium for students to present their research with their peers across the Alliance, providing the opportunity to develop and hone their networking and presentation skills.  

Data indicated URM STEM enrollment increased over the Renewal project timeline. From the baseline year (Spring 2014) to Year 5 (Spring 2019) of the project, the net Alliance-wide URM STEM enrollment increased by 4,189 students (from 7,337 to 11,526) over the baseline enrollment at the end of the previous project (Phase IV). This represents a 57.09% increase in enrollment over the period.

The number of bachelor degrees obtained by URM STEM students at the three TAMUS LSAMP Alliance institutions also increased during the Renewal project. From the baseline year (2014-2015) to Year 5 (2018-2019) of the project, a total of 7,485 STEM bachelor degrees were awarded to URM students at Alliance schools. The total number of degrees awarded in Year 5 of the Renewal project (1,881 degrees) represents a 61.5% (716 degrees) over the baseline number of total degrees awarded at the end of Phase IV (1,165 degrees). The reported numbers of URM STEM bachelor degrees increased each Renewal project year for each of the three TAMUS LSAMP institutions. 

During the Renewal project, UGR participants contributed to research papers and presentations with guidance from their faculty mentors. A subset of those products was submitted and accepted for publication in professional research journals and/or conference proceedings.  

Renewal project personnel also disseminated several papers and presentations based on our current and previous projects' successes. Dr. Frank Pezold disseminated successes and best practices of our TAMUS LSAMP at a "first-of-its-kind" forum that featured five Native American Nations: The United Houma Nation, Cherokee, Chickasaw, Potawatomi, and Choctaw from April 17-19, 2016, in Stillwater, OK. The Citizen Potawatomi Nation (CPN), in collaboration with LSAMP programs, hosted the workshop that discussed highlighting characteristics that facilitate research success for US students of color in international settings.

The TAMUS LSAMP leadership authored a paper about the Alliance's best practices that was accepted for the 2017 American Society of Engineering Education (ASEE) Annual Conference & Exposition, which was held in Columbus, OH, June 24-28, 2017. The paper, entitled TAMUS LSAMP Project: 25 Years of Success - Finding and Implementing Best Practices for URM STEM Students, chronicled activities and strategies the alliance implemented to broaden participation for URM students throughout its history. The link to the paper is https://peer.asee.org/28904.

Another paper highlighted the TAMU Engineering Transfer Scholars (ETS), an NSF S-STEM program. The paper was accepted for the 2018 ASEE Annual Conference & Exposition, which was held in Salt Lake City, UT, June 23-27, 2018. Entitled Insights on Retention of Underrepresented Minority Electrical and Computer Engineering Transfer Students, the paper chronicled activities and strategies the ETS S-STEM leadership team implemented to increase URM students' success after students transitioned to TAMU. The paper can be accessed here: https://peer.asee.org/30671.  

Dr. Samuel Merriweather disseminated information about successes and challenges of collaborations within the TAMUS LSAMP program at the Consejos Colectivos: Improving STEM Success at HSIs conference, which was funded by the NSF Hispanic Serving Institutions (HSI) program. The conference was held on February 27-28, 2018, at El Centro College in Dallas, TX. Ideas were presented on how collaborations can promote undergraduate Latinx students' success in STEM fields.
